column5: My son just applied and was told that the wait for the passport is down to 6-8 weeks.

BTW, the notarized letter from the ex or nontraveling parent(s) granting permission to travel to and from Canada for a stated purpose and period is a good idea. I suggest that you also add a sentence to the letter allowing the adult to seek necessary medical and dental care for the minor.

Just out of curosity, why not get the kids passports nonetheless? Our daughters (8 & 11 years old) have had them for years and it just makes it so easy if you want to take a trip where you will need them. For example, this August I was scheduled to go to Silver Water Wheel Lodge in Canada with my buddy. Three days befor the trip my buddies father was involved in a horrible car accident (he eventually passed away as a result). However, because of the accident there was no way my buddy could go on the Canada trip. I took my 11 year old daughter and we had an outstanding time. She has a passport (we also had my wife write a letter, however, this was never needed). We passed through the border crossing both ways with virtually no questions asked. We had another time where we were sick and tired of Chicago winter and we booked a last minute trip to the Carribean - since we all have passports this was possible. Since it sounds like you have time before your trip I'd say to just get passports. Just my $.02 Best Regards, FJH

The common misconception is that Canada requires visitors by land to have a passport. The truth is that the US will require its own citizens to have a passport to return by land or water. Many US threads on this Canada/passport issue give the impression that Canada requires the passport. As a result, I have read on such sites that US fishermen/hunters were not going to come up to Canada this year. Unfortunate for the camps and the fishermen/hunters who will miss out on a good experience. Tight Lines

My friend took his 13 year-old son with us this past summer. I advised him to go to the local driver's license bureau. For a few bucks they will provide an official photo ID. This is a pretty common request, since kids need a photo ID even to fly commercial in the US. He also got a notarized letter from his ex, which just stated everyone's full names, their relationship, and the fact that she gave permission for this travel, including the travel dates. Then no one questioned anything at the border anyway, but I'd do it again, especially in the case of a step-child, where the last names are different.
